title: "Projects"

In the summer of 2021, I took Geography 13 at UCSB. This class was a GIS course based in R. Here are the links to some of my work:

## Lab 1: [Building a project website](https://github.com/Acuevas917/acuevas917.github.io.git)

- Lab 1 was focused on building a static users site with Github Pages. 
- It includes a github repo for access to all the code.
- As my first assignment of the quarter, there were some small obstacles. I hope to clean up my work as the class progresses.

## Lab 2: [Data Wrangling](https://acuevas917.github.io/geog-13-labs/lab-02.html)

- Lab 2 was focused on data wrangling and visualization skills in R.
- By using real-time COVID-19 data, I was able to create tables and charts that could help bring light to new and cumulative COVID cases throughout the country.
- The largest obstacle I ran into with this lab was manipulating the data frame to show the data I needed. However, I was able to overcome this obstacle by test and trial of different functions/commands.


![](data:image/png;base64,)

## Lab 3: [Projections, Distances, and Mapping](https://acuevas917.github.io/geog-13-labs/lab-03.html)

- Lab 3 continued with the theme of data wrangling and visualization, and added in the practice of geo measures. This included using coordinate systems and measuring distance. 
- These skills were used to create maps of the United States and various major cities within.
- After using USA boundary data and creating maps of the United States' border zone, I was able to relate that zone to the ACLU article. The Fourth Amendment should protect this zone since most of the areas within it are considered sanctuary states/cities.
- Mapping the Border Zone was the greatest challenge in this lab. I was unable to manipulate gghighlight to show the 100 mile radius.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)


## Lab 4: [Tessellations, Spatial Joins, and Point-in-Polygon](https://acuevas917.github.io/geog-13-labs/lab-04.html)

- The cumulative pattern continues with Lab 4 as it requires skills from Labs 2 and 3, and adds in the use of tessellations, spatial joins and point-in-polygons. - Similar to Lab 3, I was able to create maps of the United States and define areas to different tessellations.
- By using real-time date of the United States' active dams, I was able to identify and highlight which dams are used for recreation, water supply, hydroelectric power, and debris control
- After building my skills throughout the quarter, Lab 4 went fairly well and I was able to work in confidence.
